2. In the 1910 census she is listed as Emma Edward.

3. The WW1 Draft Registration card for her husband Virgil in 1918 has Emma Edwards as nearest relative living in Hubbell, Thayer, Nebraska.

4. Not found in the 1920 census.

5. In the 1930 census, Emma is listed as divorced. She is also listed as age 50 making her born about 1880.

Noted events in her life were:

2. In the "U.S., World War I Draft Registration Cards, 1917-1918" database at ancestry.com Virgil is living in Sterling Weld, Colorado - Emma is in Hubbell, Nebraska

4. From www.findagrave.com:-

Mabel May Benjamin Alexander

Birth: May 15, 1879

Jackson County, Minnesota, USA

Death: Aug. 6, 1961

Fort Dodge, Webster County, Iowa, USA

Funeral services were held in the Nelson Presbyterian Church at two o'clock Wednesday afternoon for Mrs. Mabel Alexander, 82. She died early Sunday morning at Lutheran Hospital at Fort Dodge, Ia., where she had been a patient for ten days.

A former resident of Nelson, Mrs. Alexander had made her home at Fort Dodge for the past two years with her daughter, Miss Mildred Alexander, elementary supervisor of the Fort Dodge Community school district.

Mrs. Alexander was born May 15, 1879 in Jackson County, Minn. She was married to John E. Alexander at Hebron in 1899. Her husband preceded her in death as did several brothers and sisters.

Surviving are two other daughters, Mrs. A.J. (Belle) Karraker of Venango, and Mrs. Velair Miller of Glendale, Calif., and three sons, John Elmer of Lakewood, Colo., Frank of Winter Haven, Fla., and Bruce of San Marino, Calif.

The Rev. Mr. Lyle Graff of the Nelson church officiated at the Wednesday rites. Burial was made in the Edgar Cemetery.

The Nelson Gazette, Thursday, August 10, 1961

2. From www.findagrave.com:-

John Elmer Alexander, Sr

Birth: May 19, 1871

Christian County, Illinois, USA

Death: Jan. 5, 1949

Edgar, Clay County, Nebraska, USA

John Alexander, for many years one of the prominent farmers and stockmen of this county, died at 2:10 Wednesday morning at his home in Edgar. He was 77 and had been in poor health for about two years.

Mrs. Alexander, three sons and three daughters survive. Definite funeral arrangements were awaiting word from all the family.

The Nelson Gazette, Thursday, January 8, 1949

============================

John Elmer Alexander was born in Christian County, Illinois May 19, 1871, and passed away January 5th, 1949, at his home in Edgar, Nebraska, at the age of 77 years.

In his early youth he moved to Bird City, Kansas, with his parents and later to Thayer County, Nebraska, where he grew to manhood.

He was united in marriage to Mable May Benjamine January 27, 1899, at Hubbell, Nebraska. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander would have been married fifty years the 27th of this month.

To this union were born six children, all living.

In the spring of 1904 the family moved to Nuckolls county. There they resided until moving to Edgar in 1939.

He was a member of the Presbyterian Church in Edgar. He leaves to mourn his death: his wife, Mabel Alexander, and six children: Mrs. Bell Karraker, Venango; Mildred Velair Miller, Glendale, Calif.; John Elmer, Denver, Colorado; Frank Maynard, Winter Haven, Florida; L. Bruce, San Marino, California; and four grand children; one sister, Mrs. Mae Thomas of Shenandoah, Iowa.

Funeral services were held Saturday, January 8, at 2 p.m. at the Edgar Presbyterian Church with John W. Howard in charge.

J.M. McGhie, Harold McGhie, C.B. Smith, Jr. and John W. Howard sang "Beautiful Land" and "The Old Rugged Cross." Mrs. C.B. Smith, Jr. was at the organ.

Pallbearers were Charles Bush, Clark Kinnison, Nels Larson, Harry Wheeland, Asa White and Bruce Young.

Interment was in the Edgar Cemetery.

The Nelson Gazette, Thursday, January 13, 1949

Ned married ANNA BELLE CURTIS, 26 Nov, 1902, in Hebron, Thayer County, NE. She was born 24 Jul, 1885, Burchard, Pawnee County, NE, d. 25 Dec, 1978, Ovid, Sedgwick County, CO.

In 1909 they homesteaded near Peetz, Logan County, CO.

On the 1910 Federal census is Ned and Anna, with children Mildred, Verma, and Wilbur, in Iliff Precinct, Logan County, CO.

On the same 1910 census is CLARENCE, and WINNIE COLBY CURTIS, with children Viola, Bernice, and Orlin. On the same census is Anna Belle's mother, CLARISSA R. CURTIS, with children Bert, Charles, Howard, and William. Clarence was also Anna Belle's brother. They appeared to have lived next to each other, or nearby. Winnie Colby Curtis' mother JENNIE COLBY is also a neighbor with a son age 15. There is also another Colby named James with wife Alpha and son Willie age 1.

In 1914, they moved to Sedgwick County. Place uncertain at this time.

On the 1920 Fed. census is Ned and Anna Belle, with children Verma, Wilbur, Lloyd, Delma, and, Ercle, in Sedgwick, Sedgwick County, CO.

On the 1930 Fed. census is Ned and Anna Belle, with children Ethel, and Ercle, in Sedgwick, Sedgwick County, CO.

To this union, 7 children were born: MILDRED LEON, VERMA MAE, WILBUR M., LLOYD D., DELMA ETTA, ETHEL LUCILLE, and, ERCLE D.

The top photo is of Ned E. Lockwood and Anna Belle Curtis Lockwood. The photo of the child is of Ned Lockwood. Click on the photos to enlarge.

His mother, father, two brothers and two sisters preceed (sic) him in death.

He united with the christian Church in Chester at the age of 9 years and later moved his membership to the Hebron Christian Church.

Veva W. Lockwood

Birth: Jun. 20, 1916

Chase County, Nebraska, USA

Death: Jun. 19, 2015

Fort Morgan, Morgan County, Colorado, USA

Veva W. Lockwood of Holyoke was born June 20, 1916, in Chase County, Neb. She died June 19, 2015, at Valley View Villa nursing home in Fort Morgan.

She was united in marriage to Burl Lockwood Sept. 3, 1933. To this union was born four daughters and two sons. Burl and Veva worked and resided in the Holyoke area for a number of years before relocating to Westminster. They lived in Westminster for 16 years.

They returned to Holyoke, where they purchased and operated the Cedar Motel. Upon retiring, they relocated to Hot Springs, Ark., where they lived until Burls health required them to return to Holyoke. After Burls death, Veva remained in Holyoke until a decline in her health required her to relocate to Fort Morgan for medical care.

Veva was a busy wife and mother raising six children. In addition, she worked cleaning houses and in retail sales for J.C. Penney and Gambles in Holyoke and J.C. Penney in Westminster. Upon their return to Holyoke, she worked with her husband operating the Cedar Motel.

Preceding her in death were her parents, Ernest and Maude Day; her sisters, Velma Speicher and Vivian Cole; brother, LaVern Day; daughter, Phyllis Martin; grandson, Steve Bullard and wife Janel; great-grandson, Dusty Martin; and son-in-law, Ron Bullard.

She is survived by daughters, Margaret and husband James Scholl of Holyoke, Ruth and husband Joe Kinnie of Holyoke, and Judy and husband Chuck Wall of Hot Springs, Ark.; sons, Ernie and wife Nancy of Fort Morgan and Kieth and wife Barbi of Castle Pines; 13 grandchildren; 24 great-grandchildren; 20 great-great-grandchildren; two great-great-great grandchildren; and numerous nieces and nephews.

There will be no visitation. The funeral service was scheduled for Thursday, June 25, at 1:30 p.m. at Gerk Funeral Home in Holyoke, with final resting place at Holyoke Cemetery.

Dorothy Elizabeth Tamsett

August 15, 1916 - October 20, 2016

Mrs. Dorothy Elizabeth Lockwood Tamsett, age 100, entered rest on October 20, 2016. She was preceded in death by her husband Frank S. Tamsett and her son Frank, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Elizabeth Lockwood-Tamsett, daughter-in-law Pauline Tamsett, grandchildren Amy Bateman and Sean Tamsett, 4 great-grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews.

Dorothy was a long-time volunteer with the Wilford Hall Medical Center Auxiliary and served as secretary and treasurer of their board for several years. She was active for many years in the Order of the Eastern Star and was Worthy Matron of South San Antonio Chapter #691 in 1968-69. Her membership in San Antonio Assembly #159 of the Social Order of the Beauceant included service as Worthy President in 1976. In 1980, she became the founding Mighty Chosen One of Omala Caldron #99 of the Daughters of Mokanna and went on to serve the national organization as Supreme Mighty Chosen One in 1990. Despite failing vision and the limitations of her advancing years, she remained as active as possible in these organizations until her death, structuring her life in accordance with their principles and guided by her strong Christian faith.

A celebration of Dorothys life will be held at 2:00 PM on Monday, November 21, 2016 at Helotes Hills United Methodist Church, 13222 Bandera Rd., Helotes, TX, Rev. Jim Sweet officiating. Private interment will be held at Ft. Sam Houston National Cemetery, where she will be laid to rest with her beloved husband.

In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Knights Templar Eye Foundation, the Humanitarian Foundation of the Grottoes of North America or the charity of the donors choice.
